question.content:
**Which graph shows a quadratic function with domain $x<3$?**


[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes each scale by two. A graph of a line intersects the points (negative 3, 2) and (1, negative 1).

choices.content: ![A ray of a quadratic function is graphed. The x and h of x axes go from negative 10 to 10. There is an open unfilled circle at the point (3, 3). There is a curve from this point to the left that travels up to the point (negative 2, 8) and then back down to the bottom left edge of the graph.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/18c385f0fffaf55e20e323186a5edc53536a2f6a)

![A ray of a quadratic function is graphed. The x and h of x axes go from negative 10 to 10. There is a filled circle at the point (3, 3). There is a curve from this point to the left that travels up to the point (negative 2, 8) and then back down to the bottom left edge of the graph.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/87d2e481a7434919c4d243891e63cd4ad5d92a52)

![A ray of a quadratic function is graphed. The x and h of x axes go from negative 10 to 10. There is an open unfilled circle at the point (4, negative 2). There is a curve from this point to the left that travels up to the point (negative 1, 3) and then back down to the bottom left edge of the graph.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/2b77fe8a0c3fe353b10f138dc19bae473a0c9227)

![A ray of a quadratic function is graphed. The x and h of x axes go from negative 10 to 10. There is a filled circle at the point (4, negative 2). There is a curve from this point to the left that travels up to the point (negative 1, 3) and then back down to the bottom left edge of the graph.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/aa445881baec9a1e8869234ebf7a17571aaa0c69)

hints.content:
###Domain defnition

The *domain* of a function is the set of all inputs for which the function has an output. 

For this function, it's the set of all $x$ values for which the function has a $h(x)$ value.

###Endpoint observation

Notice that a domain of $x<3$ *does not* include $x=3$. This means the graph must *exclude* a point with this $x$ value.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate plane with a marked point and vertical dashed line. The x and h of x axes go from negative 10 to 10. There is an open unfilled circle at the point (3, 3). There is a dashed vertical line extending above and below this point terminating at the edges of the graph.

hints.content:
###Graph observation

The domain of $x<3$ also implies that there must be $h(x)$ values when $x$ is less than $3$. This means the graph must include points to the left.

[[☃ image 2]]

options.alt: A ray of a quadratic function is graphed. The x and h of x axes go from negative 10 to 10. There is an open unfilled circle at the point (3, 3). There is a curve from this point to the left that travels up to the point (negative 2, 8) and then back down to the bottom left edge of the graph. There is a dashed line segment from the point (3, 3) to the point (3, 0) on the x axis. There is a ray on top of the x axis from this point (3, 0) to the left edge of the graph.

A linear function is graphed. The x and y axes go from negative 10 to 10. There is a filled circle at the point (5, 4). There is a line extending from this point upwards and to the right terminating in an arrow at the end of the graph. There is a dashed vertical line between this point and the x axis. There is another filled point here on the x axis at (5, 0). There is a line on top of the x axis extending from this point to the right terminating in an arrow at the end of the graph.

hints.content:
###Solution

The following graph shows a quadratic function with domain $x<3$:

[[☃ image 2]]

options.alt: A ray of a quadratic function is graphed. The x and h of x axes go from negative 10 to 10. There is an open unfilled circle at the point (3, 3). There is a curve from this point to the left that travels up to the point (negative 2, 8) and then back down to the bottom left edge of the graph.
